data.text: Contents

Appendix 1: Doctor/Registered Nurse/Midwife Practice Assessment in obtaining Peripheral Blood Culture Sample ........................................................................................................ 11

Appendix 2: Doctor/Registered Nurse/Midwife Assessment in: Obtaining Blood Culture Sample from and Invasive Line .......................................................................................... 13
Introduction

Taking blood for culture is an important procedure as culturing microorganisms from blood can provide invaluable information relating to the diagnosis of infection (both proving and disproving the presence of infection) and bacteraemia and ensure that the patient receives optimal therapy. Used appropriately, blood cultures can help reduce morbidity and mortality and aid effective antimicrobial stewardship.

However, micro-organisms which are present on the skin surface of patients, healthcare workers and the immediate clinical environment can result in contamination of blood cultures. Contamination can cause confusion and potentially lead to unnecessary investigations and inappropriate treatment because it is sometimes difficult to determine if a positive blood culture is due to genuine bacteraemia or if it is a false positive result caused by contamination.

A false positive blood culture is defined as a growth of bacteria in the blood culture bottle that was not present in the patient's bloodstream and was introduced during sample collection. Contamination can come from a number of sources: the patient's skin, the equipment used to take the sample and transfer into the culture bottle, the hands of the person taking the blood sample or the general environment.

National expectations from the Department of Health suggest an acceptable contamination rate is less than 3%. As some patients may be unable, or unwilling to cooperate when having cultures taken this is always acknowledged within any statistical data.

Contaminated blood cultures also affect mandatory surveillance data. This can affect the trust's targets, such as the achievement of reductions in MRSA bacteraemia. It is important to take blood cultures correctly in order to minimise the risk of contamination occurring. This policy details how to take blood cultures correctly.
Scope
The aim of this policy is to ensure that blood cultures are taken:
For the correct indication
At the correct time
Using correct technique in order to prevent contamination of the sample
Minimizing risk to patients or staff
Ensuring correct documentation
Definitions

table_items.text: Presence of bacteria in the blood
For the purpose of this policy competency is deemed having assessed the relevant knowledge skills and framework to take blood culture samples.
The growth of bacteria in the blood culture bottle that was not present in the patient's bloodstream
Is defined as a growth of bacteria in the blood culture bottle that were not present in the patient's bloodstream and were introduced during sample collection.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

Trust Board has a responsibility to ensure that the risk of infection to patients, staff and visitors is minimised to its lowest potential and therefore supports the full implementation of this policy.
The Infection and Prevention Control Teams – will give advice and support on management and policy interpretation.

Site Infection Prevention and Control Committees - are responsible for the ratification of Trust wide infection prevention and control policies, procedures, and guidance, providing advice and support on the implementation of policies and monitoring the progress of the annual infection control programme.
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility and is accountable for ensuring that there is a managed environment which minimises the risk of infection to patients, visitors and staff.
The Director of Infection Prevention and Control is responsible for ensuring that there are effective and appropriate arrangements for the prevention and control of infection throughout the Trust.
Consultant Microbiologists - provides clinical advice with this policy and follow up all positive blood cultures with clinical staff.

Lead Infection Prevention and Control Nurses  - will give advice against this policy and ensure that all staff have access to this policy via the Trust Intranet sites and ensure that it is updated/ reviewed every two years or in line with current national guidance.
Heads of Department - Must ensure that appropriate training is available and that staff understand and comply with the Blood Culture Policy
Managers – will ensure that all staff are aware of and follow this policy and are aware of their own roles and responsibilities to ensure safe practice.

Staff who under take blood culture collection blood culture collection procedure must be competent to do so and have received training on the correct technique for taking blood cultures in order to prevent contamination of the sample.
Indications for taking blood cultures REMINDER
Blood cultures from a Central Venous Catheter (CVC), Hickman Line, must only be taken by staff that have been trained in the procedure and deemed as competent to do so
Blood cultures should be performed on:
5.1.1 Patients suspected of having bacteraemia, based on a combination of clinical presentation and signs:
Fever (>38oC) or hypothermia (< 35oC)
History of fevers and rigors
Unexplained haemodynamic compromise
Unexplained organ dysfunction e.g. respiratory or renal failure
A lower threshold for suspicion should be maintained in the elderly, neonates and other immunocompromised patients who may present with atypical features
5.1.2 Patients suspected of having endocarditis, discitis or other deep-seated/complex infection

5.1.3 Blood cultures should not be collected from patients who it is agreed by their responsible medical team are not for further escalation of treatment. This must be documented in the patient's medical records.
5.1.4 If blood is being collected for other tests, always collect the blood culture first
Procedure for taking blood cultures

Blood cultures should ideally be collected before starting antibiotic therapy as the yield diminishes subsequently. If endocarditis, discitis or other deep- seated/complex infection is suspected three or more culture sets are recommended, ideally at 2 – 4 hour intervals or at pyrexial peaks. When it is not possible to delay therapy, two sets may be collected at the same time, but with different venepuncture procedures.

Do not use existing peripheral lines/ cannula or sites close to existing peripheral lines. (If a central line is present, blood may be taken from this and from a separate peripheral site when investigating potential infection related to the central line: the peripheral vein sample should be collected first). Do not take samples from Arterial Lines.

Identify a suitable venepuncture site before disinfecting the skin. The sites of choice are the veins of the antecubital fossa and the hand veins. Blood cultures must not be taken through a sinus tract /broken /infected skin as there is increased risk of contamination the sample. Particular care is required in selection of venepuncture site for patients known to be colonised with Staph aureus.
Avoid femoral vein puncture because of the difficulty in adequate skin cleansing and disinfection.
Fans must be turned off during the procedure. Windows closed and no cleaning in progress .If a patient is being nursed in a side room, door must be closed
Where required ensure that communication support is available to explain the procedure to the patient
Clean plastic tray with a Clinell universal wipe, from inside to outside and allow to dry
Collect appropriate equipment and assemble, maintaining ANTT, prior to placing into the cleaned tray. Ensuring no unnecessary packing is put into the tray
Ensure the blood culture bottles to be used are in date and not already positive (the bottom of the bottle should be green prior to inoculation)
If the patient's skin is visibly soiled wash with soap and water and dry
Wash your hands
Explain and obtain consent for the procedure from the patient

Remove the plastic cover top of the blood culture bottles and disinfect each rubber bung top with a new 2% chlorhexidine in 70% isopropyl alcohol impregnated wipe for 20-30 seconds and allow to air dry
Step 2 - Taking the sample using needle and syringe
Wash and dry hands thoroughly
Apply tourniquet and palpate the vein
Clean hands with alcohol hand rub and don non sterile gloves
Clean the skin with 2% alcoholic Chlorhexidine solution (Chloraprep) and allow to dry
Insert the needle (do not palpate the vein again after cleaning the skin)
Collect the sample maintaining ANTT through the procedure
Release the tourniquet and apply pressure to achieve haemostasis
Cover the puncture site with an appropriate dressing
Inoculate the blood into culture bottles(if blood is being collected for other tests ALWAYS inoculate the blood culture bottle first )
Avoid completely emptying the syringe into the ANAEROBIC (purple) bottle as air may enter the bottle
Do not change the needle between sample collection and inoculation
Once taken, blood cultures must be sent to the laboratory as soon as possible
Step 3 – Finishing
Discard sharps into a sharps container at the point of use
Label blood culture bottles with patient's details while with the patient
Remove gloves and wash hands
Clean procedure tray with a Clinell universal sanitising wipe
Record the procedure in the patients' medical notes including the indication, date, time and site of venepuncture
Between 5pm and 8am please bleep a porter who will place them in the incubator in pathology reception
Documentation
All blood –cultures must be documented in the medical notes, including date, time, site and indications
The request forms must comply with the Trust labelling policy, be clearly signed, and have the relevant clinical details
The blood –culture bottles must have patient identifiers and site (peripheral or central clearly labelled on them without obscuring the bar code on the bottles
Do not send blood cultures to the laboratory in the air-tube system due the risk of contamination.
Training / competence

Blood cultures should only be collected by members of staff nominated by their line manager to be trained in the collection of adult blood cultures (medical, nursing/ midwife, MEA's, EDA's phlebotomists).

These members of staff must have been trained in the collection procedure and demonstrate competence. This will be assessed by their mentor or designated assessors within each business unit and reaffirmed at annual appraisal.
Training will also be provided to all staff involved in blood culture collection via eLearning.
Information on how to take blood cultures is provided via eLearning
Medical assistants will have specific training and complete initial competence assessments competency

Foundation Year 1 doctors undergo blood culture training via eLearning during their induction course, which is followed by a competency assessment. Other doctors will be offered refresher training via eLearning prior to competency assessment
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Site IPCCs, which are the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director and the Associate Director Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 3)
References
Epic3: National Evidence-Based Guidelines for Preventing Healthcare-Associated Infections in NHS Hospitals in England 2013
Saving Lives: reducing infection, delivering clean and safe care. DoH, 2007
http://www.cleansafecare  (Archived June 2010.Avalinle on the National Archives website)
The Royal Marsden Hospital Manual of Clinical Nursing Procedures, (2021). 10th edition. (Available via the library or on the intranet)
Appendix  1:  Doctor/registered  nurse/midwife  practice  assessment  in obtaining peripheral blood culture sample

table_items.text: Appropriate criteria for Blood cultures identified? E.g. Fever (>38°C) or hypothermia History of rigors / chills. Unexplained Haemodynamic compromise. Unexplained organ dysfunction. Patients with endocarditis. Senior doctor authorised test.
Print ICE Request following senior doctor authorisation Prepare equipment on dressing trolley Inform patient Perform bedside checks
Prepare area. Eg. Turn off fans and closes door
With disposable or decontaminated tourniquet, identify vein to bleed, then release tourniquet.
Prepare bottles: flip off top and mark level for blood collection (the amount of blood required is shown on the side of the bottle).
Wash hand and dry. Open dressing pack / sterile towels
Apply alcohol hand gel to hands and decontaminate.
Clean skin from anti cubital fossa to wrist with 2% alcoholic Chlorhexidine Solution (Cloraprep – FREPP) and allow to dry
Wipe over bottles with Clinell (surface) wipes and allow to dry
Do not touch skin again. Use strict aseptic technique. If skin is touched, disinfect again.

Take bloods using Vacutainer needle holder and butterfly supplied in pack and fill bottle to marked level. Fill aerobic bottle first and then anaerobic. Does not repuncture bottles Invert bottles slowly 4 times
Take other bloods, if required, remove tourniquet and needle and apply gauze to stop bleeding.
Label bottles. Check bleeding has stopped and apply a plaster.
Send sample to lab ASAP. At night, please ask porter to place in incubator in pathology reception. Do not send in air tube

data.text: Appendix 2: Doctor/registered nurse/midwife assessment in: obtaining blood culture sample from and invasive line

table_items.text: Appropriate criteria for Blood cultures identified? E.g. Fever (>38°C) or hypothermia History of rigors / chills. Unexplained Haemodynamic compromise. Unexplained organ dysfunction. Patients with endocarditis. Senior doctor authorised test documented in patient record
Print ICE Request following senior doctor authorisation Prepare equipment on dressing trolley Inform patient Perform bedside checks
Prepare area. E.g. Turn off fans and shut door
Ensure IV Line/3 Way tap is accessible

Prepare bottles: flip off top and mark level for blood collection (the amount of blood required is shown on the side of the bottle). Wipe over bottles with Clinell (surface) wipes and allow to dry. Each bottle cleaned with a separate and new Clinell
Wash hand and dry. Open dressing pack / sterile towels
Apply alcohol hand gel to hands and decontaminate. Put on sterile gloves
Place sterile towel under line/3 way tap and clean line on either side if port with Clinell swab allow to dry
Wipe over bottles with Clinell (surface) wipes and allow to dry
With sterile gauze remove cap/bionecteur from port and discard
Clean exposed port with Clinell swab and allow to dry. Attach 10ml syringe , manipulate tap and remove 5ml fluid from port. Close port and discard syringe

Apply vacutainer (for lines with easy flow back) to port, manipulate port and apply blood culture bottle. Fill to marked level Fill aerobic bottle first and then anaerobic. Does not repuncture bottles Invert bottles slowly 4 times

Attach syringe (for slow/difficult back flow), manipulate tap and remove 10ml blood. Close tap and place syringe on sterile field. Repeat procedure with second 10ml syringe. Attach a separate /new 21g needle to each syringe and insert into blood culture bottles to fill
Uses sterile gauze swab to manipulate tap. Flush line.
Attaches sterile 3 way tap or bionecteur
Send sample to lab ASAP. At night, please ask porter to place in incubator in pathology reception. Do not send in air tube
Documents in the patient record noting which port/line was sampled/aseptic technique uses and which senior doctor authorised the request.
